text: Thanks for the tip. The audience overlaps here too, which is why we're interested. I guess my question is should we aim for brand awareness or is customer acquisition also viable? What kind of goals/KPIs were you focusing on?

elements.text: Thanks for the tip. The audience overlaps here too, which is why we're interested. I guess my question is should we aim for brand awareness or is customer acquisition also viable? What kind of goals/KPIs were you focusing on?

text: I've done a bunch of these and usually set the metrics at brand awareness and referral traffic. Anything more granular I've seen is hard to track

text:
Are there folks in here who’ve successfully built and launched a new product (specifically from a marketing perspective)? Would love to learn from you :slightly_smiling_face:

Little bit of context: We’re a seed stage startup, marketing team of 3 (incl myself), building a tool to help remote teams stay & grow together,

Hypothesis: Invest 10% in making the brand look dope, 90% in content creation to build an audience. When we launch, we’ve got a list of 1000 fans

text: Thanks for all your responses. This is really helpful. Looks like Kanban view of tasks and idea collection, w/integrations to Calendars, and links out to drafts are key to everyone’s system.

text:
Anyone have a great Resources page they want to show off? Or favorites from out in the web? Looking for inspiration.

Specifically looking for pages/tabs that organize a *high volume* of assets, of *many types* (ebooks, webinars, one pagers, etc) for a *variety of audiences*. Links appreciated! :pray:

text: <@U02M5RYJA82> lots of good suggestions here. Narrative is so important to getting internal support, so think through the story you're trying to tell. Projections and forecasting with real data will help you get this right. Here's a screenshot of how I forecast traffic:

text:
Lattice does a great job: <https://lattice.com/library>

I also like the simplicity of Ramp:
<https://ramp.com/resources>

My opinion is a lot of brands try and get too fancy here and end up making navigation overly difficult. I prefer simple. Make navigation the priority. No need for a ton of bells and whistles.

attachments.text: The ultimate resource center for people management and people operations — actionable advice for HR teams, managers, executives, and employees
attachments.title: People Management and Operations Library

attachments.text: Find Ramp articles, webinars, guides, and other resources to help finance teams and founders work smarter.
attachments.title: Resources

elements.text: Oh that's rad. I've been doing some really fun stuff that's less linear looking at historical data merged with the level of effort that we'd undertake:

text: <@U01MW6DPU72> We had a few things going on. First, we wanted the initial interaction. We used utm source links to traffic clicks to our site from the post. The content itself needed to be compelling enough for people to want to click to our site for more. And we also wanted to follow up via email with the people who had engaged. That was part of the strategy as well as the partnership package. The emails sent by the partner on our behalf encouraged the engagers to come to our site and register.

elements.text: We had a few things going on. First, we wanted the initial interaction. We used utm source links to traffic clicks to our site from the post. The content itself needed to be compelling enough for people to want to click to our site for more. And we also wanted to follow up via email with the people who had engaged. That was part of the strategy as well as the partnership package. The emails sent by the partner on our behalf encouraged the engagers to come to our site and register.

text: I agree with KC, and the Lattice one is nice! I was watching a CMWorld session a few weeks ago -- I believe it was the one with Ardath Albee -- and she said she hates it when resources are organized by format. Who is thinking "I want to read a white paper?" she asked. It's more like you're thinking about the topic first: "I want to find out more about X," and then from there you can decide if you want to read a white paper or blog, or watch a video, or take a quiz, or whatever. I also love the idea of answering a few questions and voila! the results are curated based on your particular interests.

text:
Hey content crew :wave:

Has anyone put together a set of editorial guidelines? Or seen examples that you loved? I'm thinking less nitty-gritty style guide and more big-picture philosophy, content frameworks, voice and style, etc. Similar to brand guidelines I guess, but more in-depth. I'm picturing a content manifesto that acts as the North Star for editors and writers to understand how to do content well. I'm planning an overhaul of our current guidelines (specifically focused on organic SEO content) and would love input :rocket:

Thanks in advance!

(Couldn't think of a better place to ask this, but lmk if I should move it)

text: The Mailchimp one is pretty comprehensive <https://styleguide.mailchimp.com/writing-principles/>

attachments.fallback: Mailchimp: Writing Goals and Principles | Mailchimp Content Style Guide
attachments.text: Guidelines and resources for web writers and editors. Includes: voice and tone, grammar, web style, social media, email newsletters, blog posts, legal content, technical content, accessibility, translation, copyright, and more.
attachments.title: Writing Goals and Principles | Mailchimp Content Style Guide

elements.text: The Mailchimp one is pretty comprehensive

text: Good post! Gonna follow the answers. I  remember working with company that had the coolest style-guide I have ever come across. Sadly, I didn't download save that guide on my computer and thanks for unknowingly reminding me of never making that mistake again lol

text: Another thing to keep in mind with podcast strategy is that they tend to work better for nurturing and customer success than awareness or brand building. So having a strategy is important, but brand building might not be the best one since in most cases, your podcast listeners will be people already in your audience/customer base elsewhere.

elements.text: Another thing to keep in mind with podcast strategy is that they tend to work better for nurturing and customer success than awareness or brand building. So having a strategy is important, but brand building might not be the best one since in most cases, your podcast listeners will be people already in your audience/customer base elsewhere.
